# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

You can solve this problem by using the `DataFrames` package in Julia. Here is how you might do it:

```julia
using DataFrames, DataFramesMeta

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    filter!(r -> r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df
end
```

This function first uses the `filter!` function from DataFramesMeta to filter out all rows that don't match your criteria (manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro"). Then it sets a new column `audi_a4_type` to true for all remaining rows. Finally, the function returns the resulting DataFrame.

Note: This code assumes that you have already added the DataFramesMeta package to your environment by running `using DataFramesMeta`. If you haven't done this yet, run `Pkg.add("DataFramesMeta")` in the Julia REPL before trying it out.
